Award.AwardTitle: Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The fifth annual meeting of the Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS) is to be held at Florida Gulf Coast University on April 18-19, 2015. Speakers will give 30-minute research talks in various subfields of topology and algebra; these subfields include algebraic combinatorics, enumerative geometry, knot theory, and representation theory. Two distinguished graduate students will give hour-long presentations and one invited faculty member, Dr. Angelica Osorno of Reed College, will give a one-hour keynote address. Invited undergraduate researchers will participate in a poster session.

USTARS promotes diversity within the mathematical community by providing a platform for collaboration and professional development. Participants are exposed to a variety of current research, ideas, and results, and meet underrepresented professors and students who will become future collaborators or colleagues. The conference also promotes diversity by encouraging women and minorities to attend and give talks. Indeed, the conference organizing committee is diverse in gender, ethnicity, and educational background, and hence is well-positioned to encourage participation from a diverse group of students. The participants of the conference will continue to influence the next generation of students by serving as much needed mentors and encouraging students in the mathematical sciences to advance themselves and participate in research and conference events.

http://www.ustars.org/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded participant travel to USTARS 2016 at Sam Houston State University and USTARS 2017 at Amherst College.  The primary mission of the Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS) is to showcase the excellent research conducted by underrepresented students studying topology and algebra. Dedicated to furthering the success of underrepresented students, USTARS seeks to broaden the participation in the mathematical sciences by cultivating research and mentoring networks. USTARS is open to all people interested in the topological and algebraic fields.

Thanks to continued NSF support, the conference was able to provide full travel support to all graduate student participants who requested funding, and over 86 participants attended the conference and workshop at USTARS 2016.  The conference featured 18 half-hour oral presentations delivered by graduate students and 14 poster presentations by undergraduate and graduate students.  USTARS 2016 also included two 1-hour presentations delivered by Distinguished Graduate Students whose abstracts were selected by an external committee of reviewers.  Alexander Diaz-Lopez, University of Notre Dame, lectured on "Coxeter groups, peak sets, and root systems." Yen Duong, University of Illinois at Chicago, presented on "Random groups and cubulations."  The Invited Faculty Mentor, Dr. Abakuse Mbrika, Assistant Professor, University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire, delivered an inspiring keynote address, "My Combinatorial Journey through Algebra and Topology."  

For the first time, USTARS 2016 featured a one-day faculty development workshop on "Finding, Developing, and Implementing Research Opportunities." Participants in the workshop were provided with information and advice on how to fund research opportunities for their students, develop new research programs at their institutions, and implement a high-quality research experience for students, both undergraduate and graduate. Faculty from colleges and universities across the country who have experience addressing critical transition points for underrepresented graduate students were invited to act as mentors for these early career faculty.  Officers from funding agencies were also invited to provide information on how to find and apply for funding to create and develop opportunities for underrepresented students.

USTARS 2017 welcomed over 84 participants and showcased the excellent research being conducted by underrepresented graduate students by including 15 half-hour oral presentations in three parellel-sessions and 22 poster presentations in research areas including, but not limited to, algebra, topology, combinatorics, and number theory. All 15 of the talks were presented by graduate students and all 22 posters were presented by undergraduate and graduate students.

USTARS 2017 opened with a one-day early career faculty development workshop on "Writing Through Your Career."  Through a series of panels and discussions, participants were provided with information and advice on grantwriting, forming writing groups to create accountability, and compiling and writing tenure and promotion portofolios.  The conference also included two 1-hour presentations delivered by Distinguished Graduate Students whose abstracts were selected by an external committee of reviewers.  Robert Walker, a graduate student at the University of Michigan, lectured on the "Uniform Asymptotic Growth on Symbolic Powers of Ideals," and Bahar Acu, a graduate student at the University of Southern California, talked about "Symplectic mapping class group relations generalizing the chain relation." The Invited Faculty Mentor was Dr. Chelsea Walton, Selma Lee Bloch Brown Assistant Professor at Temple University. She gave an inspiring address on "Math in the Age of Trump."

Both conferences featured professional development panels where participants were invited to ask for advice on how to apply to graduate schools, find jobs, give great presentations, and become active in research opportunities.  The professional development panels consisted of groups of faculty and students of diverse backgrounds, career stages, and academic experiences. 

One of the most important outcomes of each USTARS conference is that participants are encouraged to develop a network of mentors and peers that will serve as a vital resource for collaboration and professional development throughout their careers.  The networks of new connections made at USTARS 2016 and USTARS 2017 are included as supporting images to this report.
